objdescid.compdate: c. 1780The date of this drawing is based on the "1780" date inscribed on "Albion rose," Blake's etching/engraving of the same design.

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; by inheritance to Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; apparently sold by Tatham to the dealer Joseph Hogarth; sold from Hogarth's stock, Southgate and Barrett auction, London, 7 June 1854 and seventeen following days, lot 4180 on the tenth day, with three other works by Blake (6s. to the dealer H. Palser); the dealer E. Parsons; sold by Parsons to the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1881.

desc.objtitle:
Study for "Glad Day," "Albion Rose" or "The Dance of Albion",
object 1 (Butlin 73 recto)

objnote.p: For the pencil sketch on the verso, see Study for "Glad Day," "Albion Rose" or "The Dance of Albion": The Same Figure Seen From Behind.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A single figure stands facing forward in this lightly sketched composition. Nude with relatively prominent genitals, the young male figure has short, flame-like hair standing on end and tilts his head up, creating a small shadow beneath his chin. His mouth is slightly open and he may have a faint beard. He raises both arms horizontally, palms out. His fingers, which are noticeably long, are spread with thumbs pointing up. Standing on his left leg, the figure raises his right leg at 45 degrees where his right foot appears to rest on an object (perhaps a stone or earthen mound?) defined by a single line in the lower left corner. There are several faint horizontal lines in the lower right quadrant. This figural sketch is a study for Blake's etching/engraving, "Albion rose." The figure is not specifically identified as Albion until the inscription added to the plate c. 1820.
